following:
Hami uthnaii parne vayoo desh ma neta harule dherai nai gareyy
 Pradhanmantri ko sambhodhan sunnnu vayo k india ko singh le uslai prime minister banako re
 Hami kati sahaney ho yar
llm_justification: Considering the context, the target sentence is a statement in Nepali ('Guys aba chai atti vayo') which translates to 'Guys, now this is too much' or 'This is the limit.' The surrounding text indicates a political discussion regarding the country's leadership. The statement contains no references to autism, disability, or neurodiversity, nor does it use ableist language.

preceding: This is a team game like soccer or basketball
target: Do you think that disabled gamers have the right to play even if it may negatively affect their team
following: If you had trouble maneuvering your character or had to stop and rest for 1530 seconds every 24 minutes should you still be allowed to play
llm_justification: Considering the context of competitive gaming, the text frames the participation of disabled individuals as a liability or 'negative effect' on the group. This aligns with the Burden Narrative, as it questions the fundamental right of disabled people to access a space based on the premise that their presence imposes a cost, detriment, or disadvantage upon others (the team).
llm_evidence_quote: play even if it may negatively affect their team

preceding: This is not education but indoctrination
target: It prevents students from learning about how it is immature and stupid of Oddity to intensify or perpetuate recidivism
following: It would be mature and intelligent however to recall the ideals of compassion nonviolence community and cooperation and thats why I say that theres no reason for me to go into the whole Oddity is an inarticulate jargonaut bit here
llm_justification: Considering the context, the text appears to be a general critique of a specific subject named 'Oddity' regarding 'indoctrination' and 'recidivism,' rather than a commentary on neurodivergence. While the text uses the insults 'immature' and 'stupid,' these are directed at specific behavior without referencing autism, disability, or utilizing specific anti-autistic tropes (such as the r-word or pathological framing) defined in the Knowledge Base.
llm_evidence_quote: It prevents students from learning about how it is immature and stupid of Oddity to intensify or perpetuate recidivism

preceding: he seems to show emotions of happy and sad and upset
target: im upset with myself for comparing my child to his friends or my friends kids i guess and he just isnt interested and my previous clients i worked with kids with ASD
llm_justification: Considering the context, the speaker is a parent expressing guilt and self-reflection regarding their tendency to compare their child to neurotypical peers ('upset with myself for comparing'). The text describes a personal parenting struggle and a feeling of being 'at a loss' without projecting hostility onto the child or enforcing normative standards; instead, the speaker criticizes their own impulse to compare.
llm_evidence_quote: im upset with myself for comparing my child to his friends or my friends kids

preceding: We are trapped in ASD and corporations eager for profit
target: RBTs are undertrained and more and more people are beginning to think ABA is abusive
following: What do you all see for the future
llm_justification: Considering the context, the target sentence is a critical, political statement about the quality of a specific therapy (ABA) and the training of its practitioners (RBTs). This critique, which aligns with many autistic advocates' views, does not target autistic individuals as burdensome, pathological, or inferior. Since the statement is about professional standards and perceived abuse, and not an act of anti-autistic ableism itself, it is classified as Not Ableist/Benign.
llm_evidence_quote: RBTs are undertrained and more and more people are beginning to think ABA is abusive
